awd_titl_txt: RCN-UBE: A New Faculty Development Approach to Expand Authentic Course-based Research Opportunities Focused on Microbial Bioinformatics and Functional Genomics
awd_abstract_narration:
This RCN-UBE project aims to greatly expand the incorporation of authentic genomics, bioinformatics, and functional genomics research into the undergraduate curriculum by providing training workshops, an updated Web-based genome re-annotation platform and a collaborative support network to faculty members at 2- and 4-year colleges and universities across the U.S. Biology has been transformed by the exponential increase in genomic information, but the value of that information hinges upon accurate predictions of gene function (annotation) and experimental evaluation that tests those predictions. The network will empower faculty to engage students in the concepts, skills, and experimental thinking that not only increases student scientific literacy and problem-solving abilities but also allows them to contribute to science and society right now through the deeper second-pass annotation of large numbers of genes in microbial genomes and experimental testing of predicted gene function.

Network training workshops will be based on a geographic node model wherein groups of nearby participants agree on a common meeting site and time, and then one or more trainers travel to that site to run a weekend workshop. Each workshop will focus on either (a) gene annotation (genomics and bioinformatics) and functional prediction or (b) experimental testing of gene function (functional genomics). Training in gene annotation will be broken down into several modules such as sequence similarity searches and prediction of protein localization, and will involve appropriate freely available bioinformatics tools. The use of a freely available Web platform for re-annotation of genomes from Bacteria and Archaea (GENI-ACT) allows for users to easily construct, assign, and manage gene annotations across a large number of students in multiple courses. Virtual lab notebooks for each gene annotation allow individual or collaborative work in collecting and analyzing data. The platform capability includes students combining their own bioinformatics analyses with data from the research literature and their own functional genomics efforts to reach conclusions and make the data available for the larger research community and public. Workshops on functional genomics will focus on how to bring together well-known (e.g., transposon mutagenesis, PCR) and more specialized lab strategies (e.g., site-directed mutagenesis, protein overexpression) within the context of laboratory courses to test the predicted function of genes. Participants will be encouraged to brainstorm with trainers and other participants on appropriate strategies for non-model bacterial strains and genes of interest to them. Participants will be encouraged to form collaborations within and between nearby institutions using a freely available Web teaching/research support structure (GENI-SCIENCE). Further cross-fertilization of ideas and support are provided by the network using social media tools. 

This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences (BIO), Division of Biological Infrastructure, and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources (EHR), Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action (http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/). This project is also co-funded by the Division Molecular and Cellular Biosciences (MCB) in the BIO directorate.

por.por_cntn:
The major outcomes of this project are as follows:

1) The GENI-ACT online platform, a resource for high school, community college and undergraduate instructors to teach scientific research in the classroom, is the result of the successful merger of two previous parallel efforts into a single, unique online learning and research website that took place during this grant period. The previously independent GENI-ACT and GENI-SCIENCE systems were combined into a single platform that allows users to adopt and manage both bioinformatics and bench research approaches in their classrooms.

2) New features were incorporated into the joint GENI-ACT platform and the site is now fully compatible with mobile devices. Classroom management tools allow instructors to create research teams, visualize student progress, and provide individualized student feedback. Instructors can share files (images, quizzes, presentations) both with other instructors and with students in their classroom. Seven of the 10 core project modules of the original GENI-ACT system were rewritten to provide comprehensive background information and instructions within the platform itself, rather than as supplementary materials. A tool supporting the identification of start and stop codons associated with open reading frames in Bacteria and Archaea genomes was added. Two new project modules focused on primary literature review and the integration of data from functional bench analyses were created. The user interface now includes a virtual laboratory notebook with embedded data uploads and the ability for instructors to quiz students on their knowledge and skill development during student use of the website.

3) Efforts were undertaken to grow the user community, both in terms of faculty instructors and students, through conference presentations, workshops, and one-on-one training of high school and college faculty. Over the course of this project, 157 faculty and over 2,500 students have used the GENI-ACT platform.

4) A GENI-ACT community user conference entitled "15 Years of GENI-ACT: Virtual Conference 2022" was held during the month of August 2022. User presentations were requested and high school, community college, and undergraduate instructors were all represented in the submissions. These presentations included GENI-ACT tutorials, history, classroom experiences across the 15 years that this program has been serving the educational community. The conference was asymmetric in that the interface between presenters and users was indirect. Videos were made available to watch on a private YouTube channel and questions/comments could be asked and answered via the comments section. This resource is still available for users to view on the GENI-ACT website.

 5) A key lesson learned is that nearly all instructors who learn about the teaching resources on the GENI-ACT platform are enthusiastic and excited to engage in authentic research with their students. Under our guidance, they do well in learning the basic of genomics and bioinformatics. Only later, once they return to their home institution, they are unsure that they possess the relevant skills to teach this material without continued support. In response we created our READY-TO-GO series of projects that allows users to step directly into a project with minimal prep time. These projects include all relevant background and assignments to allow instructors to implement the labs in their classrooms with only a few hours of preparation. Our core genome annotation series includes detailed background on the foundational science for each training module. Our video training series have likewise integrated background explanations of the core science required to engage an authentic research project (e.g. Using BLAST to define gene families as noted above), though this is limited in scope. Those who adopt GENI-ACT represent a subset of teachers who are deeply motivated to partner with students in this endeavor. They are willing to take the risk of learning alongside their students (not an easy task for any instructor). They are often recently graduated and have had research experience during their own academic training.
